Topics.Topic_name: Atomic Structure and the Periodic Table

Sub_topics.description: Know the structure of an atom in terms of electrons, protons and neutrons; know relative mass and relative charge of protons, neutrons and electrons.
Know what is meant by ‘atomic (proton) number’ and ‘mass number’.
Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in an atom, molecule or ion from atomic (proton) number and mass number (including accounting for ionic charge).
Understand the term ‘isotopes’ (same proton number, different neutron number/mass number).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative isotopic mass and relative atomic mass (12C scale)
Sub_topics.description: Define ‘relative isotopic mass’ and ‘relative atomic mass’ based on the 12C scale.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative molecular mass and relative formula mass
Sub_topics.description: Understand ‘relative molecular mass’ and ‘relative formula mass’ and calculate these from relative atomic masses. Note: definitions not expected; use ‘relative formula mass’ for compounds with giant structures.
Analyse and interpret mass spectrometry data to calculate relative atomic mass from relative isotopic abundance of isotopes and vice versa.
Predict mass spectra for diatomic molecules, including chlorine, including relative peak heights (using isotopic abundances; e.g. Cl2 gives peaks for 35-35, 35-37, 37-37).
Understand how mass spectrometry determines relative molecular mass from the molecular ion peak M+ (limited to using m/z of M+ as Mr).
Define ‘first ionisation energy’ and ‘successive ionisation energies’.
Understand how ionisation energies are influenced by nuclear charge (number of protons), electron shielding, and the electron sub-shell from which the electron is removed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trend: first ionisation energy across a period
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the general increase in first ionisation energy across a period (increasing nuclear charge with limited increase in shielding; include typical anomalies due to sub-shell/paired-electron effects where relevant to Edexcel).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trend: first ionisation energy down a group
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the decrease in first ionisation energy down a group (increasing distance and shielding outweigh increased nuclear charge).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for electronic structure (spectra & ionisation energies)
Sub_topics.description: Understand how ideas about electronic configuration developed from: (i) atomic emission spectra as evidence for quantum shells; (ii) successive ionisation energies as evidence for quantum shells and the group of an element; (iii) first ionisation energies of successive elements as evidence for electron sub-shells.
Know the number of electrons that can fill the first four quantum shells (2, 8, 18, 32).
Know that an orbital is a region that can hold up to two electrons with opposite spins.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shapes of s and p orbitals
Sub_topics.description: Know the shape of an s-orbital (spherical) and a p-orbital (dumbbell, oriented along axes).
Know the number of electrons that occupy s, p and d subshells (s:2, p:6, d:10).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Aufbau and Hund’s rule; electron pairing
Sub_topics.description: Know that electrons fill subshells singly before pairing up (Hund’s rule), and that two electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins.

Predict electronic configurations using 1s notation and electrons-in-boxes notation for: (i) atoms with Z up to 36; (ii) ions (s- and p-block ions only) up to Z=36 given atomic number and ionic charge.
Know that elements can be classified as s-, p- and d-block elements (by the subshell being filled).
Understand that electronic configuration determines the chemical properties of an element (valence electrons, typical ions, reactivity trends).
Understand periodicity as a repeating pattern of properties across different periods as atomic number increases and electron configurations repeat in the outer shell.

Explain trends in melting and boiling temperatures for elements in Periods 2 and 3 from given data, in terms of structure and bonding (metallic lattices, giant covalent, simple molecular; strength of intermolecular forces).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trends in ionisation energy across Periods 2 and 3
Sub_topics.description: Explain ionisation energy trends across Periods 2 and 3 using given data or recall of plots of first ionisation energy versus atomic number (including sub-shell and electron-pairing anomalies).
Illustrate periodicity using data including electronic configurations, atomic radii, melting/boiling temperatures and first ionisation energies; interpret and compare trends across periods.
Know that ionic bonding is the strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionic bonding strength: charge and radius
Sub_topics.description: Understand effects of ionic radius and ionic charge on the strength of ionic bonding (higher charge and smaller radius increase attraction).
Understand formation of ions in terms of electron loss (cations) or gain (anions).
Draw electronic configuration diagrams of cations and anions using dot-and-cross diagrams (showing electron transfer and resulting full outer shells).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trends in ionic radii (down group & isoelectronic)
Sub_topics.description: Explain trends in ionic radii down a group and across a set of isoelectronic ions (e.g. N3− to Al3+) in terms of nuclear charge and electron shielding/shells.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for ions: properties and migration
Sub_topics.description: Understand that physical properties of ionic compounds (e.g. high mp/bp, conductivity when molten/aqueous) and ion migration provide evidence for ions.
Know that a covalent bond is the strong electrostatic attraction between two nuclei and the shared pair of electrons between them.
Draw dot-and-cross diagrams for covalent substances including single/double/triple bonds and dative (coordinate) bonds, including Al2Cl6 and NH4+.
Understand relationship between covalent bond length and bond strength (shorter bonds typically stronger).
Understand that molecular/ionic shape is determined by repulsion between electron pairs (bonding and lone pairs) around a central atom.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shapes and bond angles (up to 6 pairs)
Sub_topics.description: Explain shapes and bond angles for molecules/ions with up to six outer pairs of electrons using electron-pair repulsion; examples include BeCl2, BCl3, CH4, NH3, NH4+, H2O, CO2, PCl5(g), SF6(g) and related species (including simple organic molecules in the spec).
Predict shapes and bond angles for analogous simple molecules/ions (up to six electron pairs) using electron-pair repulsion theory, including effects of lone pairs.
Know electronegativity as the ability of an atom to attract bonding electrons in a covalent bond.
Know ionic and covalent bonding are extremes of a continuum; understand electronegativity differences lead to bond polarity and can affect molecule polarity.
Understand that molecules with polar bonds may be non-polar overall depending on shape; predict whether a given molecule is likely to be polar.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Intermolecular forces: London, dipole-dipole, hydrogen bonding
Sub_topics.description: Understand intermolecular forces from: (i) London forces (instantaneous dipole–induced dipole), (ii) permanent dipole–dipole interactions, (iii) hydrogen bonding.
Understand interactions in H2O, liquid NH3 and liquid HF that give rise to hydrogen bonding (H bonded to N/O/F; lone pairs on N/O/F).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anomalous properties of water from hydrogen bonding
Sub_topics.description: Explain anomalous properties of water due to hydrogen bonding: relatively high melting/boiling points and lower density of ice compared with liquid water.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict hydrogen bonding in analogous molecules
Sub_topics.description: Predict presence/absence of hydrogen bonding in molecules analogous to those given (based on N–H/O–H/F–H and lone pairs).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Boiling points of alkanes vs chain length
Sub_topics.description: Explain trends in boiling temperatures of alkanes with increasing chain length in terms of London forces increasing with number of electrons/surface area.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effect of branching on alkane boiling points
Sub_topics.description: Explain effect of branching on boiling temperatures of alkanes (branching reduces surface area → weaker London forces → lower bp).
Explain lower volatility (higher boiling temperatures) of alcohols compared to alkanes with similar electron numbers due to hydrogen bonding.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Boiling points of hydrogen halides HF to HI
Sub_topics.description: Explain trends in boiling temperatures of HF to HI in terms of intermolecular forces (H-bonding in HF vs increasing London forces down the group).

Understand factors influencing solvent choice: (i) water dissolving some ionic compounds via hydration of ions; (ii) water dissolving simple alcohols via hydrogen bonding; (iii) water as poor solvent for compounds including polar molecules such as halogenoalkanes due to inability to form hydrogen bonds with them; (iv) non-aqueous solvents for solutes with similar intermolecular forces to the solvent (‘like dissolves like’).
Know metallic bonding is the strong electrostatic attraction between metal ions and delocalised electrons.

Know giant lattices occur in: (i) ionic solids (giant ionic lattices), (ii) covalently bonded solids such as diamond, graphite and SiO2 (giant covalent lattices), (iii) solid metals (giant metallic lattices).
Know structures of covalently bonded substances such as iodine (I2) and ice (H2O) are simple molecular (discrete molecules with intermolecular forces).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Allotropes of carbon: graphite, diamond, graphene
Sub_topics.description: Know different structures formed by carbon atoms including graphite, diamond and graphene (and relate to bonding/structure).
Predict the type of structure and bonding in a substance from numerical data and/or other information (e.g. mp/bp, conductivity, solubility).

Predict physical properties (melting/boiling temperature, electrical conductivity, solubility in water) from: (i) particles present (atoms/molecules/ions/electrons), (ii) structure, (iii) bonding and intermolecular forces where relevant.
Know what is meant by ‘oxidation number’ (oxidation state).
Calculate oxidation numbers of elements in compounds and ions; include peroxides and metal hydrides.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation/reduction as electron transfer and oxidation-number change (s/p block)
Sub_topics.description: Understand oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer and changes in oxidation number, applied to reactions of s- and p-block elements.
Understand oxidation and reduction in terms of electron loss (oxidation) or electron gain (reduction).
Know oxidising agents gain electrons (are reduced).
Know reducing agents lose electrons (are oxidised).
Understand disproportionation: an element in a single species is simultaneously oxidised and reduced.
Know oxidation number is useful for classifying reactions as redox and as disproportionation.
Indicate oxidation number of an element in a compound/ion using a Roman numeral (e.g. iron(III)).
Write formulae given oxidation numbers (ensure overall charge balance).
Understand metals generally form positive ions by loss of electrons with an increase in oxidation number.
Understand non-metals generally form negative ions by gain of electrons with a decrease in oxidation number.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Half-equations and full ionic redox equations
Sub_topics.description: Write ionic half-equations and use them to construct full ionic equations for redox reactions (balancing atoms and charge).

Topics.Topic_name: Inorganic Chemistry and the Periodic Table

Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for the trend in ionisation energy down Group 2 (increasing shielding and atomic radius).
Understand reasons for the trend in reactivity of Group 2 elements down the group (easier electron loss due to lower ionisation energy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 2 reactions with O2, Cl2 and H2O (Mg to Ba)
Sub_topics.description: Know reactions of Mg to Ba with oxygen, chlorine and water; include balanced equations and observations where relevant (e.g. Mg burns, Ca/Sr/Ba react with cold water to form hydroxide + H2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactions of Group 2 oxides/hydroxides with water/acid
Sub_topics.description: Know reactions of Group 2 oxides with water and dilute acids, and hydroxides with dilute acids (forming salts + water).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Solubility trends: Group 2 hydroxides and sulfates
Sub_topics.description: Know trends in solubility of Group 2 hydroxides (increasing down group) and sulfates (decreasing down group).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thermal stability trends of Group 1/2 nitrates and carbonates
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for trends in thermal stability of Group 1 and 2 nitrates and carbonates in terms of size and charge of the cations (polarisation of anions; ease of decomposition to oxides/carbonates).
Understand formation of characteristic flame colours by Group 1 and 2 compounds in terms of electron transitions; know required flame colours for Group 1 and 2 compounds.
Understand experimental procedures to show patterns in thermal decomposition of Group 1 and 2 nitrates and carbonates (heating, observing gases/solid products; tests for CO2/O2/NO2 as appropriate).
Understand experimental procedures to show flame colours in compounds of Group 1 and 2 elements (clean wire loop, avoid contamination, observe colours).
Understand reasons for trends in melting/boiling temperatures, physical state at room temperature, and electronegativity for Group 7 elements.
Understand reasons for trend in reactivity of Group 7 elements down the group (oxidising power decreases; electron gain less exothermic due to shielding/atomic radius).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogen displacement reactions in aqueous solution + organic solvent
Sub_topics.description: Understand trend in reactivity via redox reactions of Cl2, Br2 and I2 with halide ions in aqueous solution, followed by addition of an organic solvent (interpret colours; identify which halogen is produced).
Understand, in terms of changes in oxidation number, halogen oxidation reactions with Group 1 and 2 metals (forming metal halides).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chlorine disproportionation with water; water treatment
Sub_topics.description: Understand disproportionation of chlorine with water (Cl2 + H2O ⇌ HCl + HClO) and use of chlorine in water treatment (oxidising/disinfecting role of HClO/ClO−).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chlorine disproportionation with cold dilute NaOH (bleach)
Sub_topics.description: Understand disproportionation of chlorine with cold, dilute aqueous sodium hydroxide to form bleach (Cl2 + 2OH− → Cl− + ClO− + H2O) and oxidation numbers involved.
Understand disproportionation of chlorine with hot alkali (e.g. 3Cl2 + 6OH− → 5Cl− + ClO3− + 3H2O) and oxidation number changes.
Understand reactions analogous to the specified halogen disproportionation reactions (apply oxidation number reasoning to predict products).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Group 1 halides + concentrated H2SO4 (reducing ability trend)
Sub_topics.description: Understand reactions of solid Group 1 halides with concentrated sulfuric acid to illustrate trend in reducing ability of hydrogen halides (e.g. NaCl gives HCl; NaBr/NaI produce Br2/I2, SO2/H2S etc).

Understand precipitation reactions of Cl−, Br−, I− with aqueous AgNO3 followed by aqueous NH3 (AgCl dissolves in dilute NH3; AgBr in concentrated NH3; AgI insoluble) and write ionic equations where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hydrogen halides with NH3 and with water
Sub_topics.description: Understand reactions of hydrogen halides with ammonia (forming ammonium halides) and with water to produce acids (strong vs weak acidity trend).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict chemistry of fluorine and astatine
Sub_topics.description: Make predictions about fluorine and astatine and their compounds using knowledge of trends in halogen chemistry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Test for carbonate and hydrogencarbonate ions
Sub_topics.description: Know reactions to identify CO3^2− and HCO3− using aqueous acid to form CO2 (effervescence) and confirm CO2 (e.g. limewater turning milky). Include ionic equations where appropriate.
Know reactions to identify SO4^2− using acidified barium chloride solution (white BaSO4 precipitate). Include ionic equation Ba^2+ + SO4^2− → BaSO4(s).
Know reactions to identify NH4+ using NaOH(aq) and warming to form NH3 (pungent gas turns damp red litmus blue). Include ionic equation NH4+ + OH− → NH3 + H2O.

Topics.Topic_name: Formulae, Equations and Amounts of Substance

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mole as unit of amount of substance
Sub_topics.description: Know that the mole (mol) is the unit for amount of a substance.
Use the Avogadro constant L = 6.02 × 10^23 mol^−1 in calculations (particles ↔ moles).
Know that molar mass is mass per mole in g mol^−1; use Mr/Ar to find molar mass.
Know meanings of ‘empirical formula’ and ‘molecular formula’.
Use experimental data (mass or percentage composition by mass) to calculate empirical formulae.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Molecular formula from data (incl. pV = nRT)
Sub_topics.description: Use experimental data to calculate molecular formulae; include use of pV = nRT for gases and volatile liquids to determine molar mass.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balanced full and ionic equations with state symbols
Sub_topics.description: Write balanced full and ionic equations including state symbols for chemical reactions (spectator ions removed appropriately).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Amount calculations in reactions (mass, gas volume, solution volume, concentration)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate amounts of substances (mol) in reactions involving mass, volume of gas, volume of solution and concentration; may involve reactants and/or products.
Calculate reacting masses from chemical equations, and vice versa, using moles and molar mass (stoichiometry).
Calculate reacting volumes of gases from chemical equations, and vice versa, using amount of substance (moles) relationships.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reacting gas volumes using molar volume
Sub_topics.description: Calculate reacting volumes of gases using molar volume (including at r.t.p. 24 dm^3 mol^−1 as given in data booklet) linked to stoichiometry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 1: Molar volume of a gas
Sub_topics.description: Measure the molar volume of a gas experimentally; process data to obtain molar volume (correct unit conversions, temperature/pressure conditions per method used).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Solution concentration and titration calculations (mol dm−3 and g dm−3)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate solution concentrations in mol dm^−3 and g dm^−3, including acid-base titrations using a range of acids/alkalis and indicators; knowledge of both phenolphthalein and methyl orange indicators is expected.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 2: Standard solution and NaOH concentration
Sub_topics.description: Prepare a standard solution from a solid acid and use it to find the concentration of a sodium hydroxide solution (volumetric flask technique; titration).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 3: HCl concentration by titration
Sub_topics.description: Find the concentration of a hydrochloric acid solution using titration methods and appropriate calculations.
Calculate measurement uncertainties and measurement errors in experimental results (including combining readings, e.g. two burette readings for a titre).
Comment on sources of error in experimental procedures (systematic vs random where appropriate) and relate to uncertainty/accuracy/precision.
Understand how to minimise percentage error and percentage uncertainty in experiments involving measurements (choice of apparatus, larger measured quantities, repeated trials).

Calculate percentage yield and percentage atom economy using chemical equations and experimental results. Use: atom economy = (molar mass of desired product / sum of molar masses of all products) × 100%.
Relate ionic and full equations (with state symbols) to observations from simple test-tube reactions including displacement reactions, reactions of acids, and precipitation reactions.
Understand risks and hazards in practical procedures and suggest appropriate precautions (PPE, fume cupboard, safe heating, waste disposal) where necessary.
Know that a hydrocarbon is a compound containing hydrogen and carbon only.
Represent organic molecules using empirical, molecular, general, structural, displayed and skeletal formulae (recognise and convert between representations).
Know meanings of ‘homologous series’ and ‘functional group’.
Name compounds relevant to the specification using IUPAC rules; know prefixes up to C10 (including numbering, substituents, functional group suffixes/prefixes).
Classify reactions as addition, elimination, substitution, oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis or polymerisation.
Understand structural isomerism and determine possible structural/displayed/skeletal formulae for a given molecular formula (count distinct connectivity isomers).
Understand stereoisomerism as illustrated by E/Z isomerism, including cis-trans where two substituents are the same; apply CIP priority rules to assign E or Z where required.
Know general formula for alkanes: CnH2n+2.
Know that alkanes and cycloalkanes are saturated hydrocarbons (no C=C; cycloalkanes have single bonds).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fuels from crude oil: fractional distillation, cracking, reforming
Sub_topics.description: Understand that alkane fuels are obtained from fractional distillation, cracking and reforming of crude oil; reforming = processing straight-chain hydrocarbons into branched-chain alkanes and cyclic hydrocarbons for efficient combustion.
Know pollutants formed during combustion of alkane fuels: CO, NOx, sulfur oxides, carbon particulates, unburned hydrocarbons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Problems from pollutants (CO toxicity; acidic oxides)
Sub_topics.description: Understand problems from combustion pollutants limited to carbon monoxide toxicity and acidity of nitrogen and sulfur oxides (acid rain, environmental effects).
Understand how catalytic converters solve some pollution problems (convert CO and NOx to CO2 and N2; oxidation/reduction on catalyst surfaces).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alternative fuels: biodiesel and renewable alcohols
Sub_topics.description: Understand use of alternative fuels including biodiesel and alcohols from renewable plant sources; compare with non-renewable fossil fuels (renewability, emissions, energy content considerations).
Know a radical has an unpaired electron (shown as a single dot in mechanisms); know radicals form by homolytic fission of a covalent bond.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alkane reactions: combustion and radical substitution with halogens
Sub_topics.description: Understand alkane reactions with oxygen (combustion) and with halogens via radical substitution mechanism: initiation, propagation, termination. Note: curly half-arrows not expected.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limitations of radical substitution in synthesis
Sub_topics.description: Understand limitations of radical substitution for synthesis: further substitution leading to mixtures of products (poor selectivity).
Know general formula for alkenes: CnH2n.
Know that alkenes and cycloalkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons (contain C=C).
Understand bonding in alkenes in terms of σ-bond and π-bond (π from side-on p-orbital overlap; restricted rotation).
Know an electrophile is an electron-pair acceptor (electron-deficient species attracted to electron-rich regions).
Understand addition of H2 to alkenes in presence of Ni catalyst to form alkanes; know application to margarine manufacture by catalytic hydrogenation of unsaturated vegetable oils.
Understand addition reactions of alkenes with halogens (e.g. Br2) to form dihalogenoalkanes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alkene addition with hydrogen halides → halogenoalkanes
Sub_topics.description: Understand addition reactions of alkenes with hydrogen halides (HX) to form halogenoalkanes (regioselectivity considered later in mechanisms).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alkene hydration with steam (acid catalyst) → alcohols
Sub_topics.description: Understand addition of steam to alkenes in presence of acid catalyst to form alcohols.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation of alkenes with KMnO4 (acid) → diols
Sub_topics.description: Understand oxidation of C=C by potassium manganate(VII) in acid conditions to form a diol.
Understand heterolytic fission of a covalent bond forms ions (both electrons to one atom).
Understand electrophilic addition mechanisms between alkenes and halogens using curly arrow notation from bond/lone pair; include dipoles where relevant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrophilic addition mechanism: hydrogen halides (incl. unsymmetrical)
Sub_topics.description: Understand electrophilic addition mechanisms between alkenes and hydrogen halides, including addition to unsymmetrical alkenes; use curly arrows; include carbocation intermediate; know relative stability of primary/secondary/tertiary carbocations and its influence on product distribution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrophilic addition mechanism: other binary compounds
Sub_topics.description: Understand electrophilic addition mechanisms between alkenes and other given binary compounds (apply same mechanistic pattern with curly arrows and intermediate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Test for C=C with bromine/bromine water
Sub_topics.description: Know qualitative test for C=C: decolourisation of bromine/bromine water (orange/brown → colourless) under appropriate conditions.
Know alkenes form polymers by addition polymerisation; identify repeat unit from monomer and vice versa (showing brackets and n).
Know waste polymers can be separated into specific polymer types for: recycling, incineration to release energy, or as cracking feedstock.
Understand that considering energy and resources over the life cycle of polymer products enables more sustainable use of materials (LCA concepts applied qualitatively).
Understand how chemists limit polymer disposal problems by developing biodegradable polymers (designed to break down under conditions).
Understand how toxic waste gases from plastic incineration are removed/treated (e.g. scrubbing acid gases) to reduce environmental impact.
Know halogenoalkanes can be classified as primary, secondary, tertiary based on the carbon attached to the halogen.
Understand a nucleophile is an electron-pair donor (lone-pair/negative species) that attacks δ+ centres.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogenoalkane hydrolysis with aqueous KOH → alcohols
Sub_topics.description: Understand reactions of halogenoalkanes with aqueous KOH to form alcohols where OH− acts as nucleophile (nucleophilic substitution).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogenoalkanes with aqueous AgNO3 in ethanol (water nucleophile)
Sub_topics.description: Understand reactions of halogenoalkanes with aqueous AgNO3 in ethanol where water acts as nucleophile; interpret AgX precipitate formation as evidence of hydrolysis.
Understand reactions with KCN to form nitriles where CN− is nucleophile; know this as an example of increasing carbon chain length.
Understand reactions of halogenoalkanes with ammonia to form primary amines where NH3 acts as nucleophile (substitution).
Understand reactions of halogenoalkanes with ethanolic KOH to produce alkenes where OH− acts as a base (elimination).

Use observations/data to compare relative rates of hydrolysis of (i) primary/secondary/tertiary halogenoalkanes and (ii) chloro-/bromo-/iodoalkanes using aqueous AgNO3 in ethanol (precipitation timing).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 4: Rates of hydrolysis of halogenoalkanes
Sub_topics.description: Investigate rates of hydrolysis of some halogenoalkanes using aqueous silver nitrate in ethanol; collect time-to-precipitate data; control variables and interpret trends.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactivity trend: primary vs secondary vs tertiary halogenoalkanes
Sub_topics.description: Know trend in reactivity: tertiary > secondary > primary for nucleophilic substitution in hydrolysis (linked to carbocation stability for SN1).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactivity trend: chloro vs bromo vs iodo (bond enthalpy)
Sub_topics.description: Explain trend in reactivity of chloro-, bromo-, iodoalkanes in terms of C–X bond enthalpy (weaker bond → faster).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: SN2 mechanism: primary halogenoalkane + aqueous KOH
Sub_topics.description: Understand mechanism of nucleophilic substitution between primary halogenoalkanes and aqueous KOH (SN2), showing curly arrows from lone pair to carbon and C–X bond to halogen.
Understand SN2 mechanism between primary halogenoalkanes and ammonia to form primary amines, including need for excess NH3 and formation of ammonium salt intermediate where relevant.
Know alcohols can be classified as primary, secondary or tertiary based on the carbon bearing the –OH group.
Understand reactions of alcohols with oxygen in air (combustion) producing CO2 and H2O (complete) and CO/soot (incomplete).
Understand reactions converting alcohols to halogenoalkanes using: PCl5 → chloroalkanes; 50% conc. H2SO4 + KBr → bromoalkanes; red phosphorus + iodine → iodoalkanes (conditions and products).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oxidation of alcohols with acidified dichromate(VI)
Sub_topics.description: Understand oxidation using K2Cr2O7/H2SO4: primary alcohols → aldehydes (with Benedict’s/Fehling’s test) and further → carboxylic acids; secondary alcohols → ketones. In equations oxidising agent may be shown as [O].
Understand elimination of water from alcohols using concentrated phosphoric acid to form alkenes. Mechanisms not required.
Understand heating under reflux for preparation of liquid organic compounds (prevents loss of volatile reagents/products).
Understand extraction with a solvent in a separating funnel for separating organic and aqueous layers; density considerations; venting.
Understand distillation as a purification technique for liquid organic compounds (boiling point differences; collection range).
Understand drying an organic liquid using an anhydrous salt (e.g. MgSO4, CaCl2) and subsequent filtration/decanting.
Understand boiling temperature determination for assessing identity/purity of an organic liquid.
Carry out oxidation of ethanol under controlled conditions; obtain and test products (aldehyde vs carboxylic acid) and manage hazards of oxidisers/flammables.
Prepare tert-butyl chloride by chlorination of 2-methylpropan-2-ol using concentrated HCl; use separation/purification techniques and consider hazards (corrosive acids, volatile organics).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass spectrometry: molecular ion and Mr
Sub_topics.description: Use mass spectrometry data to determine relative molecular mass (Mr) of an organic compound from the molecular ion peak (M+).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass spectrometry: fragmentation patterns to suggest structure
Sub_topics.description: Use m/z values of fragments and fragmentation patterns to suggest possible structures of a simple organic compound (identify common fragment ions, losses, and how they relate to functional groups/structure).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IR spectroscopy: identify functional groups from spectra
Sub_topics.description: Use IR spectra to deduce functional groups and predict absorptions (given wavenumber data) for familiar groups: C–H stretches (alkanes, alkenes, aldehydes), C=C (alkenes), O–H (alcohols), C=O (aldehydes/ketones), carboxylic acids (C=O and broad O–H), N–H (amines).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 7: Analysis of inorganic and organic unknowns (I)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse some inorganic and organic unknowns using appropriate qualitative tests and instrumental/observational evidence from this part of the course (including IR where provided) to identify substances.
Know standard conditions are 100 kPa and a specified temperature, usually 298 K.
Know enthalpy change is the heat energy change measured at constant pressure.

Construct and interpret enthalpy level diagrams showing an enthalpy change with correct sign conventions for exothermic and endothermic reactions. Note: activation energy not shown on enthalpy level diagrams (but on reaction profiles).
Define standard enthalpy change of reaction, ΔrH°.
Define standard enthalpy change of formation, ΔfH°.
Define standard enthalpy change of combustion, ΔcH°.
Define standard enthalpy change of neutralisation, ΔneutH°.
Understand enthalpy measurement experiments and process results using Q = mass × specific heat capacity × temperature change (Q = mcΔT).
Evaluate sources of error and assumptions in calorimetry experiments, including mixing in insulated container, combustion using spirit burners, and situations where ΔH cannot be measured directly.
Calculate enthalpy changes in kJ mol−1 from experimental data; include correct sign and units in final answer.
Construct enthalpy cycles using Hess’s Law (including formation/combustion cycles as appropriate).
Calculate enthalpy changes from data using Hess’s Law (algebraic manipulation of cycle equations).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 8: Hess’s law enthalpy change
Sub_topics.description: Determine enthalpy change of a reaction using Hess’s Law experimentally (e.g. two related reactions, temperature changes; combine to find target ΔH).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bond enthalpy vs mean bond enthalpy
Sub_topics.description: Know meanings of ‘bond enthalpy’ and ‘mean bond enthalpy’.
Calculate enthalpy change of reaction using mean bond enthalpies (Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed)) and explain limitations (averaged values; depend on molecular environment; state differences).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mean bond enthalpy from ΔH data
Sub_topics.description: Calculate mean bond enthalpies from enthalpy changes of reaction data (rearrange and solve).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collision theory: concentration, temperature, pressure, surface area
Sub_topics.description: Use collision theory to explain effects of changing concentration, temperature, pressure and surface area on rate of reaction.
Understand reactions occur only when collisions have sufficient energy (activation energy, Ea).
Calculate rate of reaction from time taken for a reaction (e.g. 1/time for fixed amount change, where appropriate).
Calculate rate from gradient of a suitable graph by drawing a tangent (initial rate or rate at time t).
Understand qualitatively how changes in temperature affect reaction rate in terms of Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution of molecular energies (greater fraction with E ≥ Ea).
Understand role of catalysts in providing alternative reaction routes of lower activation energy.
Draw reaction profiles for uncatalysed and catalysed reactions showing relative Ea and ΔH.
Interpret catalyst action using Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution (lower Ea line; larger fraction of molecules above Ea at same temperature).
Understand use of solid heterogeneous catalysts in gas-phase industrial reactions in terms of providing a surface for reaction (adsorption, reaction, desorption).
Understand economic benefits of catalysts in industry (lower temperature/pressure, faster rate, improved yield/selectivity, lower energy costs).
Know reversible reactions can reach dynamic equilibrium where forward rate = backward rate and concentrations of reactants/products remain constant.
Predict and justify qualitative effects of changes in temperature, concentration or pressure on a homogeneous equilibrium system (Le Chatelier’s principle; consider exo/endo and gas moles).
Evaluate data to explain why industrial processes often require compromise between yield and rate of reaction (consider equilibrium position vs kinetics; temperature/pressure/catalyst).
Deduce expression for Kc for homogeneous and heterogeneous systems in terms of equilibrium concentrations (omit solids and pure liquids).
Deduce expression for Kp for homogeneous and heterogeneous systems in terms of equilibrium partial pressures (in atm as specified).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate Kc and Kp from data (with units)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate values (with units where appropriate) of equilibrium constants Kc and Kp for homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions from experimental equilibrium data (concentrations/partial pressures).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Temperature effect on K (exo vs endo)
Sub_topics.description: Know effect of changing temperature on Kc and Kp for exothermic and endothermic reactions (K changes with T; increases for endothermic on heating, decreases for exothermic).
Understand temperature effects on position of equilibrium are explained using change in the value of equilibrium constant.
Understand equilibrium constant value is not affected by changes in concentration or pressure, or by adding a catalyst (though equilibrium position may shift when concentrations/pressures changed).
Know a Brønsted–Lowry acid is a proton donor and a Brønsted–Lowry base is a proton acceptor.
Know acid-base reactions involve transfer of protons (H+).
Identify Brønsted–Lowry conjugate acid-base pairs in equations.
Define pH (pH = −log10[H+]).
Calculate pH from hydrogen ion concentration [H+] (mol dm−3).
Calculate [H+] from pH using [H+] = 10^−pH (mol dm−3).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strong vs weak acids (degree of dissociation)
Sub_topics.description: Understand difference between strong and weak acids in terms of degree of dissociation (complete vs partial ionisation).
Calculate pH of a strong acid from its concentration (assume complete dissociation; account for stoichiometry if polyprotic not required here—spec says monobasic in curves later).
Deduce expression for acid dissociation constant Ka for a weak acid and carry out calculations using Ka = ([H+][A−])/[HA].
Calculate pH of a weak acid making relevant assumptions (e.g. [H+] << [HA]initial) and check validity where appropriate.
Define ionic product of water Kw = [H+][OH−].

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: pH of strong bases using Kw
Sub_topics.description: Calculate pH of a strong base from concentration using Kw (find [OH−], then [H+] = Kw/[OH−], then pH).
Define pKa = −log10Ka and pKw = −log10Kw.
Analyse data from experiments measuring pH of substances including equimolar solutions of strong and weak acids, strong and weak bases, and salts; relate to dissociation/hydrolysis where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Experiment data: dilution of strong vs weak acids
Sub_topics.description: Analyse data comparing pH of a strong acid and a weak acid after dilution by factors of 10, 100 and 1000 (interpret changes based on dissociation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ka from pH and mass of acid
Sub_topics.description: Calculate Ka for a weak acid from experimental data given pH of a solution containing known mass of acid (convert mass→moles→concentration, set up equilibrium).
Draw and interpret titration curves for all combinations of strong and weak monobasic acids and bases (equivalence point pH, buffer region, curve shape).
Select a suitable indicator using a titration curve and appropriate data (indicator transition range vs steep region; methyl orange/phenolphthalein etc).
Know what is meant by a buffer solution (resists pH change on addition of small amounts of acid/base).
Understand action of a buffer solution in terms of equilibrium shift of a weak acid/base and its conjugate (e.g. HA/A−) consuming added H+ or OH−.
Calculate pH of a buffer solution given appropriate data (use Ka and concentrations; may use Henderson–Hasselbalch where derived/appropriate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Preparing buffer of given pH (required concentrations)
Sub_topics.description: Calculate concentrations/amounts required to prepare a buffer solution of a given pH (choose ratio [A−]/[HA] using Ka).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weak acid–strong base curve: buffer demonstration
Sub_topics.description: Use weak acid–strong base titration curve to demonstrate buffer action (buffer region before equivalence; resistance to pH change).
Determine Ka from pH at half-neutralisation point in weak acid–strong base titration (pH = pKa when [HA]=[A−]).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: ΔHneut differences: strong vs weak acids
Sub_topics.description: Understand why enthalpy changes of neutralisation differ for strong vs weak acids (energy required to ionise weak acid reduces exothermicity; strong acids fully ionised).
Understand roles of carbonic acid (H2CO3) and hydrogencarbonate (HCO3−) ions in controlling blood pH (buffer equilibrium; response to added acid/base; link to CO2).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 9: Determining Ka of a weak acid
Sub_topics.description: Find Ka value for a weak acid experimentally (measure pH of known concentration or use titration curve/half-neutralisation method) and process data appropriately.
Define lattice energy as the energy change when one mole of an ionic solid is formed from its gaseous ions.
Define enthalpy change of atomisation, ΔatH (formation of 1 mol gaseous atoms from element in standard state).
Define electron affinity (enthalpy change when 1 mol gaseous atoms/ions gain electron(s) to form 1 mol gaseous anions; first EA typically exothermic).
Construct Born–Haber cycles and carry out calculations (use ΔfH°, ΔatH, ionisation energies, electron affinities, lattice energy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lattice energy as ionic bond strength measure
Sub_topics.description: Know lattice energy provides a measure of ionic bond strength (more negative → stronger ionic bonding).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Experimental vs theoretical lattice energy and covalency
Sub_topics.description: Understand comparing experimental lattice energy (from Born–Haber) with theoretical value (electrostatic model) indicates degree of covalent character in a compound.
Understand polarisation as applied to ions (distortion of electron cloud of anion by cation leading to covalent character).
Know polarising power of a cation depends on its radius and charge (small, highly charged cations polarise most).
Know polarisability of an anion depends on its radius and charge (large, highly charged anions more polarisable).
Define enthalpy change of solution, ΔsolH, and enthalpy change of hydration, ΔhydH.

Use energy cycles and energy level diagrams to calculate enthalpy change of solution, enthalpy change of hydration and lattice energy (link: ΔsolH = ΣΔhydH − lattice energy when lattice energy defined for formation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting lattice energy (charge and radius)
Sub_topics.description: Understand effect of ionic charge and ionic radius on lattice energy (higher charge, smaller ions → more negative lattice energy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting hydration enthalpy (charge and radius)
Sub_topics.description: Understand effect of ionic charge and ionic radius on enthalpy change of hydration (higher charge density → more negative ΔhydH).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why ΔH alone doesn’t determine spontaneity
Sub_topics.description: Understand that some endothermic reactions occur at room temperature, so enthalpy changes alone do not control whether reactions occur.
Know entropy is a measure of disorder; natural direction of change is increasing total entropy (positive ΔStotal).
Explain entropy changes during changes of state (S(s) < S(l) < S(g); increased particle freedom).
Explain entropy changes when dissolving a solid ionic lattice (increased disorder due to separated hydrated ions vs ordered lattice).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Entropy changes: change in moles of gas
Sub_topics.description: Explain entropy changes in reactions with change in number of moles from reactants to products (especially gas moles; more moles → higher entropy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Discuss reactions in terms of entropy and enthalpy (examples)
Sub_topics.description: Discuss typical reactions in terms of disorder and enthalpy change including: dissolving NH4NO3 in water; reacting ethanoic acid with ammonium carbonate; burning Mg ribbon in air; mixing Ba(OH)2·8H2O(s) with NH4Cl(s).
Understand total entropy change: ΔStotal = ΔSsystem + ΔSsurroundings.
Calculate ΔSsystem for a reaction from entropies of reactants and products (ΣS°products − ΣS°reactants), with units J mol−1 K−1.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculate ΔSsurroundings and ΔStotal from ΔH/T
Sub_topics.description: Calculate entropy change in surroundings using ΔSsurroundings = −ΔH/T and hence find ΔStotal (consistent units; T in K; ΔH in J mol−1).
Know feasibility depends on balance of entropy and enthalpy; represented by ΔG = ΔH − TΔSsystem.
Use ΔG = ΔH − TΔSsystem to predict whether a reaction is feasible (ΔG < 0 feasible; ΔG > 0 not feasible under conditions).
Use ΔG = ΔH − TΔSsystem to determine temperature at which a reaction is feasible (solve for T when ΔG = 0).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Link between ΔG and equilibrium constant K
Sub_topics.description: Use ΔG = −RT ln K to show feasible reactions (negative ΔG) have large K and vice versa (under stated conditions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why negative ΔG may not occur in practice
Sub_topics.description: Understand why a reaction with negative ΔG may not occur in practice (kinetic inhibition; high activation energy; slow rate; lack of suitable pathway).
Know reactions that are thermodynamically feasible may be inhibited by kinetic factors (rate considerations; catalysts).
Understand oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer, applied to s-, p- and d-block elements.
Understand oxidation and reduction in terms of changes in oxidation number, applied to s-, p- and d-block elements.
Know what is meant by standard electrode potential, E° (potential of a half-cell relative to standard hydrogen electrode under standard conditions).
Know standard electrode potentials refer to: 298 K, 100 kPa gas pressure, and 1.00 mol dm−3 ion concentrations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) and reference electrode role
Sub_topics.description: Know features of standard hydrogen electrode and why a reference electrode is necessary (defined potential 0.00 V; allows comparison).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measuring E° for metal/non-metal with its ions
Sub_topics.description: Understand methods to measure standard electrode potentials for metals or non-metals in contact with their ions in aqueous solution (half-cells, salt bridge, voltmeter).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measuring E° for same element, different oxidation states
Sub_topics.description: Understand methods to measure E° for ions of the same element with different oxidation numbers (e.g. Fe3+/Fe2+, VO2+/VO2+ systems).
Investigate electrochemical cells: set up cells, measure voltages, vary half-cells/conditions, and interpret results relative to standard electrode potentials.
Calculate standard emf E°cell by combining two standard electrode potentials (E°cell = E°(cathode) − E°(anode); using reduction potentials).
Write cell diagrams using conventional representation of half-cells (phase boundaries |, salt bridge ||; include inert electrodes Pt/graphite when needed).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Importance of conditions when measuring electrode potential E
Sub_topics.description: Understand importance of conditions for electrode potential E (non-standard concentrations/pressures/temperature alter E; Nernst ideas qualitative).
Predict thermodynamic feasibility of a redox reaction using standard electrode potentials (positive E°cell implies feasible under standard conditions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: E°cell proportional to ΔStotal and ln K
Sub_topics.description: Understand E°cell is directly proportional to total entropy change and to ln K for a reaction (linking electrochemistry and thermodynamics).
Understand limitations of predictions using E°: kinetic inhibition and departure from standard conditions can prevent/alter observed reaction direction.
Know standard electrode potentials can be listed as an electrochemical series (more positive = stronger oxidising agent for reduction half-equation).
Understand how disproportionation relates to standard electrode potentials (intermediate oxidation states unstable when E° comparisons favour both oxidation and reduction).
Understand application of electrode potentials to storage cells (e.g. predicting voltage, direction of reactions, recharging concept).
Understand that energy released by reaction of a fuel with oxygen is used in a fuel cell to generate a voltage; know methanol and other hydrogen-rich fuels may be used.
Know electrode reactions in hydrogen–oxygen fuel cells with acidic and alkaline electrolytes (anode oxidation of H2; cathode reduction of O2; overall 2H2 + O2 → 2H2O).
Carry out structured and non-structured redox titration calculations including Fe2+/MnO4− in acid and iodine–thiosulfate I2/S2O3^2− systems (use balanced half/full equations and mole ratios).
Understand methods used in redox titrations (choice of oxidant/reductant, indicators such as KMnO4 self-indicating; starch for iodine; endpoint detection; acidification requirements).
Perform a redox titration (e.g. Fe2+ with MnO4− or iodine/thiosulfate), including preparation, accurate burette/pipette technique, and calculations for concentration.
Deduce electronic configurations of atoms and ions of Period 4 d-block elements Sc–Zn given atomic number and charge (include removal of 4s electrons before 3d for ions).
Know transition metals are d-block elements that form one or more stable ions with incompletely filled d-orbitals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Variable oxidation states in transition metals
Sub_topics.description: Understand why transition metals show variable oxidation number (similar energies of 4s and 3d electrons; variable loss of electrons).
Know what is meant by the term ‘ligand’ (species donating lone pair to form coordinate bond).
Understand that dative (coordinate) bonding is involved in forming complex ions (ligand lone pair → metal ion).
Know a complex ion consists of a central metal ion surrounded by ligands.
Know transition metals form coloured ions in solution (contrast with s/p block).
Understand colour of aqueous ions and other complexes results from splitting of d-orbital energy levels by ligands (d–d transitions absorb visible light).
Understand lack of colour in some aqueous ions/complexes (e.g. d0 or d10 configurations; no d–d transitions in visible).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Causes of colour changes in transition metal complexes
Sub_topics.description: Understand colour changes can arise from changes in oxidation number, ligand, or coordination number (affecting d-orbital splitting).
Understand meaning of ‘coordination number’ (number of coordinate bonds between ligands and central metal).
Understand why H2O, OH− and NH3 are monodentate ligands (one lone pair donor site).
Understand why six-coordinate complexes are octahedral, e.g. complexes with H2O, OH−, NH3 ligands ([M(H2O)6]n+, etc.).
Know transition metal ions may form tetrahedral complexes with relatively large ligands such as Cl− (e.g. [CoCl4]2−).
Know square planar complexes are formed; cis-platin is an example (Pt(NH3)2Cl2 in cis geometry).
Understand why cis-platin is supplied as a single isomer not mixed with trans form (different biological activity; trans less effective).
Identify bidentate ligands (e.g. NH2CH2CH2NH2) and multidentate ligands (e.g. EDTA4−).
Know haemoglobin is an iron(II) complex containing a multidentate ligand (haem group structure not assessed).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ligand exchange in haemoglobin (O2 vs CO)
Sub_topics.description: Know ligand exchange occurs when O2 bound to haemoglobin is replaced by CO (explains CO toxicity due to stronger binding).
Know colours of vanadium compounds/ions for oxidation states +5, +4, +3 and +2 (as required by Edexcel practical contexts).
Understand redox reactions interconverting vanadium oxidation states (+5, +4, +3, +2) in terms of relevant E° values (predict feasible steps and reagents/conditions).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dichromate(VI) reduced to Cr3+ and Cr2+ using Zn/H+
Sub_topics.description: Understand, using relevant E° values, that Cr2O7^2− can be reduced to Cr3+ and Cr2+ using zinc in acidic conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chromate/dichromate produced by oxidation of Cr3+ using H2O2/alkali then acid
Sub_topics.description: Understand, using E° values, that Cr2O7^2− can be produced by oxidation of Cr3+ using hydrogen peroxide in alkaline conditions followed by acidification (via chromate formation).
Know dichromate(VI) ⇌ chromate(VI) equilibrium: 2CrO4^2− + 2H+ ⇌ Cr2O7^2− + H2O; predict shifts with acid/base and associated colour changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reactions of TM ions with NaOH and NH3 (observations + equations)
Sub_topics.description: Record observations and write suitable equations for reactions of Cr3+(aq), Fe2+(aq), Fe3+(aq), Co2+(aq) and Cu2+(aq) with aqueous NaOH and aqueous NH3, including in excess (precipitates, colours, complex formation, amphoteric behaviour).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ligand exchange vs amphoteric behaviour (ionic equations)
Sub_topics.description: Write ionic equations to show difference between ligand exchange and amphoteric behaviour for reactions of transition metal ions with OH−/NH3 (e.g. dissolution of Al(OH)3 vs complex formation for Cu2+).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cu(II) ligand exchange with NH3 (tetraammine complex)
Sub_topics.description: Understand ligand exchange and colour change forming [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)2]2+ from [Cu(H2O)6]2+ via Cu(OH)2(H2O)4 intermediate/precipitate stage.
Understand formation of [CuCl4]2− from [Cu(H2O)6]2+ via ligand exchange (colour change; conditions with concentrated chloride).
Understand ligand exchange and colour change forming [CoCl4]2− from [Co(H2O)6]2+ (often via adding concentrated HCl/Cl−; coordination number change).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Coordination number changes with ligand substitution
Sub_topics.description: Understand substitution of small uncharged ligands (H2O) by larger charged ligands (Cl−) can change coordination number (e.g. octahedral to tetrahedral).
Understand substitution of monodentate ligands by bidentate/multidentate ligands increases complex stability due to large positive ΔSsystem (chelate effect).
Know transition metals and their compounds can act as heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts (due to variable oxidation states, complex formation, adsorption).
Know a heterogeneous catalyst is in a different phase from reactants and reaction occurs at the catalyst surface (adsorption, reaction, desorption).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: V2O5 catalyst in Contact Process (oxidation number)
Sub_topics.description: Understand, in terms of oxidation number changes, how V2O5 acts as catalyst in the Contact Process (SO2 + O2 ⇌ SO3; V(V)/V(IV) redox cycle).
Understand how catalytic converters decrease CO and NO emissions by: adsorption of CO/NO on surface, weakening bonds and reaction, desorption of CO2 and N2 products.
Know a homogeneous catalyst is in same phase as reactants; understand catalysed reaction proceeds via intermediate species.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fe2+ catalysis of I− with S2O8^2−
Sub_topics.description: Understand role of Fe2+ ions in catalysing reaction between I− and S2O8^2− ions (redox cycle Fe2+/Fe3+ as intermediate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mn2+ autocatalysis of MnO4− with C2O4^2−
Sub_topics.description: Know role of Mn2+ ions in autocatalysing reaction between MnO4− and C2O4^2− ions (product Mn2+ increases rate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 12: Transition metal complex preparation
Sub_topics.description: Prepare a transition metal complex; apply safe technique, purification where needed, and record observations (colour, yield) linked to coordination/ligands.

Understand terms: rate of reaction, rate equation, order with respect to a substance, overall order, rate constant k, half-life, rate-determining step, activation energy, heterogeneous and homogeneous catalyst.
Determine and use rate equations of form rate = k[A]^m[B]^n where m and n are 0, 1 or 2 (including units of k depending on overall order).
Select and justify suitable experimental technique to obtain rate data for a reaction, including: titration, colorimetry, mass change, volume of gas evolved, or other suitable technique(s).
Understand initial-rate method using separate experiments with different initial concentrations; clock reactions acceptable approximation.
Understand continuous monitoring to generate data for concentration–time or volume–time graphs (e.g. gas collection, colorimetry).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate and half-life from first-order graphs
Sub_topics.description: Calculate rate and half-life of a first-order reaction from concentration–time or volume–time graph data (recognise constant half-life; use ln relationships if supplied/derived).
Deduce order (0,1,2) with respect to a substance using concentration–time graph data (shape, linearity of appropriate plots, half-life behaviour).
Deduce order (0,1,2) with respect to a substance using rate–concentration graph data (direct proportionality, squared relationships, independence).
Deduce order (0,1,2) using initial-rate data (compare experiments; method of initial rates; calculate rate ratios and concentration ratios).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Iodination of propanone: obtain data for orders (incl. [H+])
Sub_topics.description: Understand how to obtain data to calculate orders with respect to reactants (and hydrogen ion) in acid-catalysed iodination of propanone.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict species in rate-determining step from rate data
Sub_topics.description: Use rate data to make predictions about species involved in the rate-determining step of iodination of propanone.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce mechanism for iodination of propanone
Sub_topics.description: Deduce a possible mechanism for acid-catalysed iodination of propanone based on deduced rate equation/orders and stoichiometry.
Deduce a rate-determining step from a rate equation and deduce a rate equation from a proposed rate-determining step (including pre-equilibria if stated).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mechanisms from rate equation and stoichiometry
Sub_topics.description: Deduce reaction mechanism using rate equation information together with stoichiometric equation (identify intermediates; consistent elementary steps).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Halogenoalkane hydrolysis: evidence for SN1 vs SN2 from kinetics
Sub_topics.description: Understand how rate equations for hydrolysis of halogenoalkanes provide evidence for SN1 (tertiary) and SN2 (primary) mechanisms.
Use graphical methods to find activation energy from experimental data (Arrhenius equation provided if needed; plot ln k vs 1/T; gradient = −Ea/R).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 13a: Iodine–propanone rate by titration
Sub_topics.description: Follow rate of iodine–propanone reaction by titrimetric method to obtain rate data and determine orders/rate equation elements.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 13b: Clock reaction (Harcourt–Esson iodine clock)
Sub_topics.description: Investigate a clock reaction (Harcourt–Esson iodine clock) as an approximation to initial-rate method; collect timing data and interpret rate trends.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 14: Activation energy of a reaction
Sub_topics.description: Find activation energy experimentally by measuring rate at different temperatures and using appropriate plotting method (Arrhenius) to calculate Ea.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Optical isomerism from chirality (single chiral centre)
Sub_topics.description: Know optical isomerism results from chirality in molecules with a single chiral centre.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chiral centres and non-superimposable mirror images
Sub_topics.description: Understand optical isomerism arises from chiral centre(s) (asymmetric carbon atom(s)) and optical isomers are non-superimposable mirror images.
Know optical activity: a single optical isomer rotates plane of polarisation of plane-polarised monochromatic light (in molecules containing a single chiral centre).
Understand nature of a racemic mixture (equal amounts of enantiomers; no net rotation due to cancellation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Optical activity evidence for SN1 vs SN2
Sub_topics.description: Use data on optical activity of reactants/products as evidence for SN1 (racemisation) and SN2 (inversion) mechanisms.
Identify aldehyde (–CHO) and ketone (>C=O) functional groups in structures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carbonyl intermolecular forces and physical properties
Sub_topics.description: Understand aldehydes/ketones do not form intermolecular hydrogen bonds; relate to physical properties (lower bp than alcohols of similar Mr).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carbonyl hydrogen bonding with water and solubility
Sub_topics.description: Understand aldehydes/ketones can form hydrogen bonds with water; relate to solubility trends (smaller carbonyls more soluble).

Understand reactions of carbonyl compounds with Fehling’s/Benedict’s solution, Tollens’ reagent and acidified dichromate(VI) ions: aldehydes oxidised; ketones generally not. Oxidising agent may be represented as [O] in equations.
Understand reduction of aldehydes/ketones with LiAlH4 in dry ether; reducing agent may be shown as [H] in equations (aldehyde → primary alcohol; ketone → secondary alcohol).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nucleophilic addition of HCN to carbonyls (mechanism + chirality)
Sub_topics.description: Understand nucleophilic addition of HCN (with KCN) to aldehydes/ketones; show mechanism with curly arrows, relevant lone pairs and dipoles; use evidence of optical activity (formation of chiral centre → racemic mixture) where relevant.
Understand 2,4-DNPH as qualitative test for carbonyl group (orange/yellow precipitate) and identification of carbonyl compound using melting point data of derivatives; equation not required.

Understand reaction with iodine in alkali (iodoform reaction) for compounds containing CH3CO– or CH3CH(OH)– groups (yellow CHI3 precipitate) and apply to relevant carbonyls/alcohol oxidation products.
Identify carboxylic acid functional group –COOH.
Understand hydrogen bonding affects boiling temperatures and solubility of carboxylic acids (dimer formation; trends with chain length).
Understand preparation of carboxylic acids by oxidation of alcohols or aldehydes and by hydrolysis of nitriles.
Understand reaction of carboxylic acids with LiAlH4 in dry ether (reduction to primary alcohol; use [H] notation if required).
Understand reactions of carboxylic acids with bases to produce carboxylate salts (including with carbonates/hydroxides; CO2 effervescence with carbonates).
Understand reactions of carboxylic acids with phosphorus(V) chloride (PCl5) producing acyl chlorides (plus POCl3 and HCl).
Understand ester formation from carboxylic acids and alcohols in presence of acid catalyst (reversible; equilibrium; water formed).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Identify acyl chloride and ester groups
Sub_topics.description: Identify acyl chloride (–COCl) and ester (–COOR) functional groups.
Understand reaction of acyl chlorides with water (hydrolysis) producing carboxylic acid + HCl (fumes, vigorous).
Understand reaction of acyl chlorides with alcohols producing esters + HCl (nucleophilic acyl substitution).
Understand reaction of acyl chlorides with concentrated ammonia producing primary amides + ammonium chloride (HCl neutralised).
Understand reaction of acyl chlorides with amines producing substituted amides + ammonium salts (acylation).
Understand ester hydrolysis in acidic conditions (reversible, gives carboxylic acid + alcohol) and alkaline conditions (saponification, effectively irreversible, gives carboxylate salt + alcohol).
Understand how polyesters form by condensation polymerisation reactions (diol + dicarboxylic acid / acyl chloride; ester links).
Understand benzene bonding models: Kekulé alternating double bonds vs delocalised π model (overlap of p-orbitals forming delocalised π system).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for delocalisation (ΔHhydrogenation and bond lengths)
Sub_topics.description: Understand evidence for delocalised benzene model from enthalpy changes of hydrogenation (less exothermic than expected for 3 isolated C=C) and equal C–C bond lengths (intermediate between single and double).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why benzene resists bromination vs alkenes
Sub_topics.description: Understand why benzene is resistant to bromination compared with alkenes due to stabilisation from delocalised π system and lower localised electron density than alkene π bond; requires catalyst to generate electrophile.
Understand benzene combustion in air gives smoky flame (high C:H ratio; soot) and combustion products CO2/H2O.
Understand benzene reaction with bromine in presence of catalyst (e.g. FeBr3/AlBr3) to form bromobenzene + HBr (electrophilic substitution).
Understand nitration of benzene using concentrated nitric and sulfuric acids to form nitrobenzene + water (electrophilic substitution).
Understand benzene reactions with halogenoalkanes and acyl chlorides using AlCl3 catalyst (Friedel–Crafts reactions) to form alkylbenzene or acylbenzene; electrophilic substitution.

Understand mechanisms of benzene electrophilic substitution (halogenation, nitration, Friedel–Crafts), including generation of the electrophile, formation of arenium ion intermediate, and regeneration of aromaticity; use curly arrows appropriately.
Understand reaction of phenol with bromine water (rapid substitution, decolourisation, formation of 2,4,6-tribromophenol precipitate).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why phenol brominates more easily than benzene
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for easier bromination of phenol than benzene (lone pair donation from O into ring increases electron density; activates ring; no catalyst needed).
Identify amine and amide functional groups in structures (primary/secondary/tertiary amines; –CONH– for amides).
Identify molecules that are amino acids (contain both –NH2 and –COOH groups; 2-amino acids emphasis).
Understand reaction of primary aliphatic amines (e.g. butylamine) with water to form alkaline solution (amine as Brønsted base; equilibrium producing OH−).
Understand reaction of primary aliphatic amines with acids to form ammonium salts (protonation).
Understand reaction of primary aliphatic amines with ethanoyl chloride to form substituted amides + HCl (nucleophilic acyl substitution).

Understand reaction of primary aliphatic amines with halogenoalkanes (nucleophilic substitution) leading to further substitution and possible quaternary ammonium salts; need for excess amine to favour primary amine products when preparing amines.
Understand reaction of primary aliphatic amines with copper(II) ions to form complex ions (ligand behaviour; colour change).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Basicity trends: NH3 vs aliphatic vs aromatic amines
Sub_topics.description: Understand reasons for differences in basicity of ammonia, primary aliphatic amines and primary aromatic amines using data (inductive effect increases basicity in aliphatic; delocalisation of lone pair into benzene ring decreases basicity in aromatic).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare primary aliphatic amines from halogenoalkanes
Sub_topics.description: Understand reagents and conditions to prepare primary aliphatic amines from halogenoalkanes (nucleophilic substitution with NH3; excess NH3; ethanol solvent; heat in sealed tube).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prepare primary aliphatic amines by nitrile reduction
Sub_topics.description: Understand preparation of primary aliphatic amines by reduction of nitriles (e.g. LiAlH4 or catalytic hydrogenation; product chain lengthened relative to halogenoalkane).
Know aromatic nitro-compounds can be reduced using tin and concentrated HCl to form aromatic amines (e.g. nitrobenzene → phenylamine), followed by base to liberate free amine.
Understand amides can be prepared from acyl chlorides (reaction with ammonia or amines; conditions; by-products).
Know formation of a polyamide is a condensation polymerisation reaction (amide links formed with elimination of small molecule such as H2O/HCl).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Repeat units: polyester from dicarboxylic acid + diol
Sub_topics.description: Draw structural formula of repeat unit of condensation polymer formed from dicarboxylic acids and diols (polyester).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Repeat units: polyamide from dicarboxylic acid + diamine
Sub_topics.description: Draw structural formula of repeat unit of condensation polymer formed from dicarboxylic acids and diamines (polyamide).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Repeat units: polymers from amino acids
Sub_topics.description: Draw structural formula of repeat unit of condensation polymer formed from amino acids (polyamide/polypeptide link).
Understand 2-amino acids exist as zwitterions in solution and show both acidic and basic behaviour (internal proton transfer; reactions with acids/bases).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Optical activity of amino acids solutions
Sub_topics.description: Understand effect of aqueous solutions of (chiral) amino acids on plane-polarised monochromatic light (optical activity; racemic vs pure enantiomer).
Understand peptide bond in proteins forms when amino acids combine by condensation polymerisation (–CO–NH– link; elimination of H2O).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protein hydrolysis and amino acid chromatography
Sub_topics.description: Understand peptide bonds can be hydrolysed to form constituent amino acids, which can be separated by chromatography (Rf comparison; visualisation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Core Practical 15: Analysis of inorganic and organic unknowns (II)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse some inorganic and organic unknowns using a broader range of tests/techniques from across the course (including chromatography and other relevant methods) to identify unknown substances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deduce structures from combined analytical data
Sub_topics.description: Deduce empirical, molecular and structural formulae from combustion analysis, elemental percentage composition, characteristic functional-group reactions, IR spectra, mass spectra and NMR spectra (integrate multiple evidence sources to identify compounds).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plan multi-step organic syntheses (up to 4 steps)
Sub_topics.description: Plan reaction schemes of up to four steps to form familiar and unfamiliar compounds (choose reagents/conditions; functional group interconversions; carbon chain changes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Grignard reagents: formation and reactions (CO2, carbonyls)
Sub_topics.description: Understand chain-lengthening using magnesium to form Grignard reagents (RMgX) and their reactions with carbon dioxide and with carbonyl compounds in dry ether (followed by hydrolysis to alcohols/acids).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Select and justify practical procedures and risk controls (organic)
Sub_topics.description: Select and justify suitable practical procedures for reactions involving specified functional groups, including identifying appropriate control measures to reduce risk based on hazard data (e.g. flammable solvents, corrosives, toxics).
Understand refluxing as a technique in preparation/purification of organic compounds (safe heating, condenser, anti-bumping).
Understand purification by washing (removing impurities using aqueous washes such as NaHCO3, water, brine) and choosing appropriate wash based on acid/base properties.
Understand solvent extraction (partitioning between immiscible solvents; separating funnel) as part of organic purification.
Understand recrystallisation to purify an organic solid (choice of solvent, dissolving hot, crystallising on cooling, filtration, drying).
Understand drying of organic products (use of drying agents; removal before final isolation).
Understand distillation for purification, including steam distillation for heat-sensitive/immiscible substances (co-distillation with water).
Understand melting temperature determination to assess purity/identity of organic solids (impurities lower and broaden melting range).
Understand boiling temperature determination for organic liquids (purity/identity; boiling range).

Prepare aspirin (2-ethanoyloxybenzoic acid) via acylation of salicylic acid; purify product (recrystallisation), determine melting temperature, calculate yield, and manage hazards (acids, acylating agents).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: High-resolution MS: suggest structures from accurate mass
Sub_topics.description: Use mass spectra data (accurate to four decimal places) to suggest possible structures of a simple organic compound given accurate relative molecular mass (use molecular formula determination via exact mass).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: High-resolution MS: calculate accurate Mr and identify compound
Sub_topics.description: Calculate accurate relative molecular mass using relative atomic masses to four decimal places and identify compound by matching to accurate mass data.
Understand that 13C NMR provides information about positions/environments of 13C atoms in a molecule (chemical shift δ).
Use 13C NMR data (chemical shift δ) to predict different environments for carbon atoms in a molecule.
Justify number of peaks in a 13C NMR spectrum based on number of non-equivalent carbon environments (including symmetry considerations).
Understand high-resolution proton (1H) NMR provides information about positions/environments of 1H atoms in a molecule.
Use 1H NMR chemical shift δ values to predict different types of proton present (e.g. alkyl, adjacent to electronegative atoms, aldehydic, aromatic).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Use integration (peak areas) to get proton ratios
Sub_topics.description: Relate relative peak areas (integration) or ratio numbers to relative numbers of 1H atoms in different environments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Splitting patterns using (n+1) rule; deduce structure
Sub_topics.description: Deduce splitting patterns of adjacent non-equivalent protons using (n+1) rule and use splitting + shifts + integration to suggest possible structures for a molecule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Predict 1H chemical shifts and splitting for given molecules
Sub_topics.description: Predict chemical shifts and splitting patterns for 1H atoms in a given molecule (apply typical δ ranges and coupling to neighbouring protons).
Know chromatography separates components of a mixture between a mobile phase and a stationary phase (different affinities/partitioning).
Calculate Rf values from one-way chromatograms: Rf = distance moved by solute / distance moved by solvent front.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: HPLC and GC as column chromatography; retention times; MS coupling
Sub_topics.description: Know HPLC and GC are types of column chromatography; separate due to different retention times; may be used with mass spectrometry in applications such as forensics or drug testing in sport.
